title: 103_hr2040
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission on the Dual-Use Application of Facilities and Resources at White Sands Missile Range Act". Congress finds that the end of the Cold War allows for a reduction in defense spending, creating an opportunity to utilize defense-related equipment in the private sector for economic growth. The Department of Defense has invested in research and development of such technologies, including those at White Sands Missile Range, but lacks guidance on their utilization. The Department of Defense has not adequately studied or provided guidance for defense-related facilities, equipment, processes, and technologies for private sector use. A study of White Sands Missile Range could examine these resources and their potential dual-use applications by scientific personnel. Establishing a commission for this study would provide timely information on utilizing these assets in the private sector. Establishment of Commission for studying defense-related facilities, equipment, processes, and technologies for private sector use. The Commission on the Dual-Use Application of Facilities and Resources at White Sands Missile Range is established with 10 members appointed by the Secretary of Defense, including individuals with experience in cooperative research and development agreements and dual-use technologies from Department of Energy national laboratories, corporations working with Department of Defense or Department of Energy, and experts in commercial utilization or application. The Commission on the Dual-Use Application of Facilities and Resources at White Sands Missile Range is established with 10 members appointed by the Secretary of Defense, including experts in commercial utilization of high technology by the private sector. Members serve for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Six members constitute a quorum, with the Commission selecting a Chairman from among its members. Meetings are held at the call of the Chairman, with the Commission terminating one year after all members have been appointed. The Commission on the Dual-Use Application of Facilities and Resources at White Sands Missile Range will study how defense-related equipment can be utilized by the private sector. A report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations will be submitted to relevant committees within a year of all members being appointed. The Commission has the power to conduct this study and make legislative and administrative recommendations. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, receive evidence, and administer oaths. It can also obtain information from Federal agencies and delegate its powers. Additionally, the Commission can use the postal service. Commission personnel matters are also addressed. The Commission members are compensated for their duties, with non-government members receiving a daily rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also provided travel expenses while on duty. Additionally, an executive director is appointed with compensation not exceeding the prescribed rate. The executive director of the Commission can appoint additional personnel and set their compensation. Service on the Commission or employment by the Commission does not conflict with federal laws on conflicts of interest or employment restrictions. Service on the Commission or employment by the Commission does not count as service in a government position for certain legal purposes. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out the purposes of this Act.
